image.altText: A black and white image of murder victim Frank Foley.

items.synopsis: Human remains located by a fossicker last year have been linked to Frank Foley's close-living relatives, and police will conduct a forensic search at the site today.

title.children: Queensland police hope 'offenders can be brought to justice' after cold case breakthrough

image.altText: A dark-haired boy standing on a boardwalk in bushland. His face is blurred and he cannot be identified.

items.synopsis: The boy's devastated family has been told he is likely to spend months in hospital. A 27-year-old man has been charged over the Sunshine Coast incident.

title.children: Boy, 12, on life support after being knocked off scooter by alleged drunk driver on Father's Day

image.altText: a composite image of two boys, seen from behind

items.synopsis: Brothers Kaleb and Jonathan*, then aged 19 and 17, were found in May 2020 after their father was discovered dead from a terminal illness at their Brisbane home.

title.children: Queensland government should compensate teens with autism found living in filth, royal commission finds

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: The judge overseeing a criminal trial into the deadly eruption of Whakaari White Island in 2019 dismisses charges against the three brothers who own the volcano, with proceedings set to continue over their company's involvement.

title.children: Judge in Whakaari White Island trial dismisses charges against brothers who own volcano

image.altText: A close-up of a man with cropped dark hair.

items.synopsis: Darryl Valroy Young, the man accused of killing three family members at a remote cattle farm last year, has appeared in court for the first time in months.

title.children: Man charged with murder over shooting deaths of three people at Bogie attempts to represent himself in court

image.altText: A young boy is smiling in a red t-shirt.

items.synopsis: A Sydney court hears secret recordings in which William Tyrrell's former foster father appears to berate a child in an expletive-laden tirade as he fights charges of assault and intimidation.

title.children: William Tyrrell's former foster father appears to berate a child in secret recording played to court

image.altText: A keyboard lights up in darkness

items.synopsis: Six Queensland men are charged with more than 100 child sex offences following extensive investigations connected to taskforce Argos detectives.

title.children: Six Queensland men charged with more than 100 child sex offences, 15,000 cases referred to child safety

image.altText: A man in a high-vis work shirt being led in handcuffs

items.synopsis: Five men accused of orchestrating a low altitude "black flight" to import $15 million of methamphetamine through a country Queensland airstrip have had their cases mentioned in court.

title.children: Phone taps, surveillance handed over in case against alleged 'black flight' meth smugglers

image.altText: A long-haired man in a black wetsuit stands on the sand, holding a long yellow surfboard with a snake on the front of it.

items.synopsis: Shiva the surfing python has become an overnight sensation after footage of her gliding through Rainbow Bay went viral. Watch the video.

title.children: 'She's a natural': Meet the surfing snake turning heads in the waves at Snapper Rocks

image.altText: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce speaks to the media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Embattled Qantas boss Alan Joyce brings his retirement forward by two months after a horror period for the airline.

title.children: Alan Joyce abruptly departs Qantas after scandalous week and 'many ups and downs'

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe, wearing earrings in the colours of the Aboriginal flag, sits in the senate, she looks up to the left

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe reveals her unlikely friendships with political adversaries, and says she was once approached by former Victorian premier Jeff Kennett to run for the Liberal Party.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe reveals her 'weird' and unlikely friendships in the Senate

image.altText: A red illuminated Westpac bank logo on a black wall with a blurred man walking past

items.synopsis: Westpac is facing civil court proceedings from ASIC, which alleges it failed to respond to hardship requests within the time required by law.

title.children: Cars and property seized after Westpac failed to respond to hardship requests, ASIC alleges

image.altText: A seven-month-old boy with scratches on his face and head.

items.synopsis: Seven-month-old Jack had been left alone, unsupervised, in a room when he was beaten by another child. His mother is now pursuing legal action and lawyers say their caseload of injuries sustained at childcare centres is increasing.

title.children: Injuries sustained at childcare centres are on the rise. Experts say there's one common factor

image.altText: Dozens of photos, most arranged on top of each other, on a table

items.synopsis: Three decades after the legendary Queen frontman's death, more than 250 snaps from his personal albums are released publicly for the first time, painting a new picture of a world only his "nearest and dearest" knew until now.

title.children: Freddie Mercury's 'mythology busting' private photos revealed after 30 years

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has announced he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. And the Reserve Bank is expected to keep interest rates on hold today at 4.1 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Alan Joyce to leave Qantas tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months, ASX lower ahead of RBA decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Last week we heard that Australia Post swung from swung from profit to loss for the financial year, because of higher losses from its letters business. That's as people send fewer letters and foot traffic at post offices slumps. Now Australia Post has asked the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission if it can raise the Basic Postage Rate from $1.20 to $1.50 from January 2024. The postal service says the proposed increase will help address the rising cost of delivering letters and reduce losses. "Australia Post reported a $384.1 million loss in its letters business over 2023, and estimates the cost of meeting its community service obligations of $442 million. Australia Post has not proposed a change to the $0.60 price of concession stamps or the $0.65 price of seasonal greetings stamps. The prices of these stamps have not changed since they were launched nearly 10 years ago. Australia’s domestic stamp rate continues to be one of the lowest in the OECD and has increased by just $0.20 in the past seven years. The average household sends around 15 letters a year and, if implemented, the proposed increase would cost about $4.50 extra a year." Australia Post wants to reduce the frequency of daily letter deliveries and close some metro post offices to save money as the Federal Government consults on the future of the postal service. Chief executive Paul Graham says Australia Post is committed to keeping its letters business, but says this is only possible if the business is financially sustainable. “We’ve made a number of changes in the past year to improve and simplify our business but, as we are entirely self-funded and receive no ongoing government funding, we need to ensure we reduce losses in our letters business. “We’re committed to maintaining the letters service for communities across Australia and increasing the Basic Postage Rate will help us continue to deliver for all Australians."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia Post applies to increase stamp prices

children.content: Last week we heard that Australia Post swung from swung from profit to loss for the financial year, because of higher losses from its letters business.
That's as people send fewer letters and foot traffic at post offices slumps.
Now Australia Post has asked the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission if it can raise the Basic Postage Rate from $1.20 to $1.50 from January 2024.
The postal service says the proposed increase will help address the rising cost of delivering letters and reduce losses.
"Australia Post reported a $384.1 million loss in its letters business over 2023, and estimates the cost of meeting its community service obligations of $442 million.
Australia Post has not proposed a change to the $0.60 price of concession stamps or the $0.65 price of seasonal greetings stamps.
The prices of these stamps have not changed since they were launched nearly 10 years ago.
Australia’s domestic stamp rate continues to be one of the lowest in the OECD and has increased by just $0.20 in the past seven years.
The average household sends around 15 letters a year and, if implemented, the proposed increase would cost about $4.50 extra a year."
Australia Post wants to reduce the frequency of daily letter deliveries and close some metro post offices to save money as the Federal Government consults on the future of the postal service.
Chief executive Paul Graham
says Australia Post is committed to keeping its letters business,
but says this is only possible if the business is financially sustainable.

“We’ve made a number of changes in the past year to improve and simplify our business but, as we are entirely self-funded and receive no ongoing government funding, we need to ensure we reduce losses in our letters business.
“We’re committed to maintaining the letters service for communities across Australia and increasing the Basic Postage Rate will help us continue to deliver for all Australians."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank is expected to keep official interest rates on hold this afternoon at 4.1 per cent with the market predicting a 95 per cent chance of no change. AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina says the softening in inflation this year is in line with their expectations based on leading indicators of producer prices, commodity prices, manufacturing surveys, other business surveys, and the global economy. AMP expects inflation to slow further by the end of the year and they are predicting consumer inflation to come in at 4 per cent, near the RBA's forecast of 4.1 per cent. Consumer inflation eased to 4.9 per cent over the 12 months to July with housing and food the most significant price rises, offset by falling petrol prices. Ms Mousina sees little reason for an increase to rates at today's meeting and she thinks that rates are likely to remain unchanged for the rest of 2023, with a chance of rate cuts next year. Here's an interview I did with Diana Mousina last month on ABC News Channel after the unemployment rate rose from 3.5 per cent to 3.7 per cent in July.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMP predicts no more RBA interest rate rises

children.content: The
Reserve Bank
is expected to keep official interest rates on hold this afternoon at 4.1 per cent with the market predicting a 95 per cent chance of no change.
AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina

says the softening in inflation this year is in line with their expectations based on leading indicators of producer prices, commodity prices, manufacturing surveys, other business surveys, and the global economy.
AMP expects inflation to slow further by the end of the year and they are predicting consumer inflation to come in at 4 per cent, near the RBA's forecast of 4.1 per cent.
Consumer inflation eased to 4.9 per cent over the 12 months
to July with housing and food the most significant price rises, offset by falling petrol prices.
Ms Mousina sees little reason for an increase to rates at today's meeting and she thinks that rates are likely to remain unchanged for the rest of 2023, with a chance of rate cuts next year.
Here's an interview I did with Diana Mousina last month on ABC News Channel after the unemployment rate rose from 3.5 per cent to 3.7 per cent in July.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 index -0.5%) is trading lower as banks and commodity stocks pull down the market ahead of the RBA's latest decision on interest rates. The RBA is expected to stay on hold at 4.1 per cent. Most sectors are in the red with utilities, energy, and miners leading the losses. Mineral explorer Chalice Mining is taking a hit amid the fallout from its over optimistic assessment of commodity prices for its Julimar nickel-copper project. Stockbroker Jefferies has downgraded the explorer from hold to underperform saying that the "unattractive economics" of Juliimar are not yet fully factored into the share price. And this burn: "Assumed commodity prices for the valuation of the project did not represent the common practice of using consensus or lower to validate a project's robust economics." And Qantas (+0.4%) is higher after Alan Joyce stepped down. Top movers: BrainChip: +3.2% Iress: 2.4% Megaport: +1.6% Chalice Mining: -17.2% West African Resources: -4.7% Bellevue Gold: -4.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

ASX 200 index -0.5%)

The RBA is expected to stay on hold at 4.1 per cent.

Mineral explorer

image.altText: A grey tabby feral cat against a background of red dirt.

items.synopsis: A new global report is released, providing the most comprehensive assessment on biological invasions to date.

title.children: UN report warns Australia is in the hot seat on invasive species, but there is some good news

image.altText: An aerial photo of a coal power plant surrounded by Australian bush.

items.synopsis: The NSW government will "engage with Origin Energy" on a proposed extension of the life of Australia's largest power plant.

title.children: NSW government moves to delay closure of Australia's largest coal-fired power station

image.altText: A woman lies back in a chair smiling, while someone injects her forehead with a syringe.

items.synopsis: Australia's medical regulator says it is cracking down on cosmetic procedures such as botox and fillers, but those living with the long-term impacts of botched procedures say the focus has come too late.

title.children: Cosmetic surgery crackdown now targeting fillers, botox and other procedures

image.altText: Lauren Brockhurst - female ringer

items.synopsis: Once considered a man's job, the number of women working on cattle and sheep stations across Australia appears to be increasing. But it doesn't come without its challenges.

title.children: Meet the outback ringers proving women can do more than 'wear nice neck scarves and take cute photos'

image.altText: Man in white shirt

items.synopsis: Jurors have been told not be to be tempted to be television detectives when deliberating the fate of a man police allege gave a toddler a fatal dose of an antidepressant.

title.children: Jury hears man charged over toddler's antidepressant death 'not sharpest knife in the drawer', but not a killer

image.altText: A street with police on it

items.synopsis: A 35-year-old woman is in a critical condition and a teenager is in hospital after being stabbed multiple times at a property in north-west Queensland.

title.children: Woman fights for life after double stabbing in outback Queensland home

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

title.children: Brisbane Airport curfew and flight cap would push up airfares, says aviation expert

image.altText: a woman in a white dress with her arms out standing on the sand

items.synopsis: They're integral to Australia's tourism and agriculture industries, but backpacker numbers dropped with travel restrictions during COVID-19.

title.children: Has Australia got its backpackers back? This data suggests so

image.altText: artwork of man in foreground and newspaper in the background

title.children: At 100, Alan McClure is still fuelled by homemade sausage rolls, love and finding humour in the everyday

title.children: Spain's men's team condemns Rubiales' 'unacceptable behaviour' that 'tarnished' World Cup win
